Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: TC3 - Triboluminescent Crack Categorization Coating

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop new materials, applied in the form of paints, for damage detection in bridges. These paints are unique in that they emit a visible light signal as cracks propagate through them. This allows an inspector to identify and monitor active cracks during visual inspection of bridges and other civil infrastructure. The project combines the development and processing of luminescent paints with the testing of these materials as sensors for crack detection and categorization in civil infrastructures. The paints will be studied by a combination of laboratory experiments, which includes the design of new material compositions, and the field-testing of the paints on both in-service and decommissioned bridges, which will allow development of field protocols for use of these materials. The emphasis is on systematically optimizing basic materials processing and behavior that will result in enhanced signal strength during field use and developing a model that describes the luminescent response of a variety of materials for crack detection. The project is divided into two parts: (1) the development of luminescent powders and their incorporation into slurries to form a paint mixture that can be applied to structures and (2) the testing of these materials under realistic conditions for assessment of their effectiveness for structural health monitoring, specifically detection and categorization of fatigue cracks.

If successful, the benefit of this research will be the development of unique paints that can visually detect active cracks in bridges, increasing the effectiveness of the visual inspection and the timeliness of repair strategies. As many state and federal agencies develop a replacement and rehabilitation strategy for aging infrastructure, this is an opportune time to integrate an innovative sensing methodology that exploits all available material advancements. An innovative monitoring tool that provides real-time information, does not require a power source, and is visual, would be a significant advancement in the area of fatigue crack detection. This tool could be integrated during hands-on inspection or during rehabilitation of bridge structures.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the UNH-portion of this project is to develop a fatigue cracking detection coating system using triboluminescent powders develop as the University of California at San Diego.  The milestone goals  for this project include the design and development a testing procedure to capture the triboluminescent crack detect, selection of the appropriate paint structure and composite for the coating system and the optical parameter for the crack detection camera systems. Two main products of this project were (1) a non-contact low-cost measurement technique for structural performance of in-service bridge structures and (2) multi-scale modeling protocols for fatigue design and condition assessment of bridge connection.  This modeling protocol was demonstrated on the Memorial Bridge in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, see Figure 1.

Goal 1.  Development of a non-contact sensing system to capture the strain in the member and visual light emitted from the triboluminescent coating. The application of the coating to an in-service bridge structure was planned for the final stage of development of this system. Due to delays in the development of the coating, This project focused on the non-contact measurement technique. Figure 2 show the application of non-contact strain measurement and traditional strain measurement at the Bagdad Road Bridge in Durham, NH and the comparison the collected strain values.

The data collection system for these test was a digital image correlation system of non-contact strain measurement using GoPro® cameras.  This sensor system was successfully deployed in multiple laboratory experiments, as shown in Figure 3, and a field deployment at the Bagdad Road over US Route 4 Bridge in Durham, New Hampshire. This system was deployed on a curved steel surface in the laboratory in anticipation of application on the cold-formed curved flanges of the gusset-less connections at the Memorial Bridge. This system was deployed at the Memorial Bridge on the curved flanges of the gusset-less connection in October 2017.  Due to adverse weather conditions this test was not successful.

There is benefit of an easy-to-deploy, low-cost and accurate means of strain measurement for in-service structures. As the transportation industry adopts data-driven asset management protocol through Federal Highway Administration’s MAP21 (Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century - https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/map21/),  field-ready means of collecting objective structural performance data will be critical.  The use of GoPro® cameras will help state transportation officials develop smart inspection procedures as a low capital investment cost.

Goal 2.  Development of a modeling protocol to design innovative bridge connection in terms of fatigue performance.  This project funded the development of a detailed finite element model to predict fatigue behavior in truss connections, see Figure 4, and an in-service bridge assessment protocol using building information modeling technology and digital photographs to track maintenance needs and condition of structural and mechanical components.

Professor Bell and civil engineering graduate students, Maryam Mashayekhizadeh and Milad Mehrkesh, created a set of multi-scale finite element models to predict structural performance and fatigue assessment. These models includes small detailed models focused on the connection zone and large scale models with a varying level of detail for different elements of the bridge.  One model is a 3D frame model of the south span and tower in SAP2000. This coarse-scale model is appropriate for investigating the gross response of the bridge to dynamic excitation and will be calibrated using acceleration data from the structural health monitoring sensor network. The second model is a 3D finite element (FE) model in LUSAS and the third is a detailed FE model of the gusset-less connection zone in ABAQUS. The FE models will be used in conjunction with the strain data from the structural health monitoring sensor network to investigate the stress distributions and fatigue in the gusset-less connections. A preliminary structural response calibration was performed as part of this project, see Figure 5.  A more in detailed model verification will continue as part of the NSF-funded Living Bridge project (01430260)

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The major goal of the UNH-portion of this project is to develop a fatigue cracking detection coating system using triboluminescent powders develop as the University of California at San Diego. The milestone goals for this project include the design and development a testing procedure to capture the triboluminescent crack detect, selection of the appropriate paint structure and composite for the coating system and the optical parameter for the crack detection camera systems. Two main products of this project were (1) a non-contact low-cost measurement technique for structural performance of in-service bridge structures and (2) multi-scale modeling protocols for fatigue design and condition assessment of bridge connection. This modeling protocol was demonstrated on the Memorial Bridge in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, see Figure 1. Goal 1. Development of a non-contact sensing system to capture the strain in the member and visual light emitted from the triboluminescent coating. The application of the coating to an in-service bridge structure was planned for the final stage of development of this system. Due to delays in the development of the coating, This project focused on the non-contact measurement technique. Figure 2 show the application of non-contact strain measurement and traditional strain measurement at the Bagdad Road Bridge in Durham, NH and the comparison the collected strain values. The data collection system for these test was a digital image correlation system of non-contact strain measurement using GoPro® cameras. This sensor system was successfully deployed in multiple laboratory experiments, as shown in Figure 3, and a field deployment at the Bagdad Road over US Route 4 Bridge in Durham, New Hampshire. This system was deployed on a curved steel surface in the laboratory in anticipation of application on the cold-formed curved flanges of the gusset-less connections at the Memorial Bridge. This system was deployed at the Memorial Bridge on the curved flanges of the gusset-less connection in October 2017. Due to adverse weather conditions this test was not successful. There is benefit of an easy-to-deploy, low-cost and accurate means of strain measurement for in-service structures. As the transportation industry adopts data-driven asset management protocol through Federal Highway Administration?s MAP21 (Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st Century - https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/map21/), field-ready means of collecting objective structural performance data will be critical. The use of GoPro® cameras will help state transportation officials develop smart inspection procedures as a low capital investment cost. Goal 2. Development of a modeling protocol to design innovative bridge connection in terms of fatigue performance. This project funded the development of a detailed finite element model to predict fatigue behavior in truss connections, see Figure 4, and an in-service bridge assessment protocol using building information modeling technology and digital photographs to track maintenance needs and condition of structural and mechanical components. Professor Bell and civil engineering graduate students, Maryam Mashayekhizadeh and Milad Mehrkesh, created a set of multi-scale finite element models to predict structural performance and fatigue assessment. These models includes small detailed models focused on the connection zone and large scale models with a varying level of detail for different elements of the bridge. One model is a 3D frame model of the south span and tower in SAP2000. This coarse-scale model is appropriate for investigating the gross response of the bridge to dynamic excitation and will be calibrated using acceleration data from the structural health monitoring sensor network. The second model is a 3D finite element (FE) model in LUSAS and the third is a detailed FE model of the gusset-less connection zone in ABAQUS. The FE models will be used in conjunction with the strain data from the structural health monitoring sensor network to investigate the stress distributions and fatigue in the gusset-less connections. A preliminary structural response calibration was performed as part of this project, see Figure 5.
